I have had several reach out [and] I\xe2\x80\x99m confident I\xe2\x80\x99ll find a better home.\xe2\x80\x9d

FROM COINAGE: Outed as Transgender on Reality TV: Survivor\xe2\x80\x99s Zeke Smith

This season of Survivor, dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cGame Changers\xe2\x80\x9d for its 34th installment, had been filmed 10 months ago in the Mamanuca Islands of Fiji \xe2\x80\x94 though Varner couldn\xe2\x80\x99t discuss what happened until the episode\xe2\x80\x99s airing.

During that time, he said he\xe2\x80\x99s done a lot of growing.

\xe2\x80\x9cI have spent 10 months stewing in this awful, horrible mistake I have made,\xe2\x80\x9d Varner told EW Morning Live (Entertainment Weekly Radio, SiriusXM, channel 105) on Thursday. \xe2\x80\x9cI have been through, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how much therapy. With the show\xe2\x80\x99s therapist, with a local therapist. I have met with and spoken to several LGBT organizations \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99ve joined the board of a couple of them\xe2\x80\xa6 this has changed me drastically.\xe2\x80\x9d

As tough as it\xe2\x80\x99s been for him, Varner recognizes that Smith, 29, is the real victim in this situation.

\xe2\x80\x9cThis is about Zeke,\xe2\x80\x9d Varner said. \xe2\x80\x9cI can only profusely apologize. I have apologized to him \xe2\x80\x94 we\xe2\x80\x99ve spoken several times on the phone. He continually forgives me. I am amazed and moved at his ability to do that. I know that forgiveness is difficult. I know that he has a lot of people in his ear. I know that watching this last night was traumatic not only for me and my family \xe2\x80\x94 I can only imagine what this was like for him and his friends and everybody who loves him.\xe2\x80\x9d

\xe2\x80\x9cI hurt him,\xe2\x80\x9d Varner continued. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen we were in pain and we are in fair, we are dangerous people. We say things we don\xe2\x80\x99t mean. And he\xe2\x80\x99s calling me a bigot and full of hate and all kinds of stuff. I forgive him for that. I give him every inch of every room to feel and experience what he\xe2\x80\x99s feeling. If he wants to take swings at me, I\xe2\x80\x99m the one to hand him the bat. I deserve it. I deserve every bit of it. No one is going to beat me up worse than I have myself.\xe2\x80\x9d

\xe2\x80\x9cI think he hoped others would believe that trans people are dangerous and fraudulent,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat reasoning is infinitely worse than him outing me because it\xe2\x80\x99s the same one used to discriminate against, attack and murder trans people. What\xe2\x80\x99s great is that nobody bought it.\xe2\x80\x9d

\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s important people see he lost that fight,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cThe message should be clear that hate will always lose.\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'When Sarah Herron went on The Bachelor in 2012, she did it for herself. What she never expected was how the experience would motivate her to help others.

"I originally signed up for The Bachelor because I was so insecure with my arm that I couldn't date," she tells ET. "I thought, as crazy it sounds, maybe if I ... go on and my story's out there for everyone to see, I can't hide from it anymore. When the show aired and I started getting messages from girls across the country who could relate, that was when I realized what an incredible opportunity I had been given."

Herron is "limb different," she was born with only one fully-formed arm. The 30-year-old didn't win Bachelor Sean Lowe's heart, but she walked away from the experience with much more: the beginnings of an idea. Herron continued living in California, working and even went on Bachelor in Paradise twice before the way she could use her time on reality TV came to her in full. It was actually season two of BIP, and a terrible experience with infamous "villain" Chad Johnson, that helped.

Bachelor in Paradise Premiere: How The Show Handled Corinne Olympios, DeMario Jackson Scandal

"He said some pretty offensive things that were specifically targeted at my arm, and that kind of all made it seem like, this is a better chance than ever to start an organization," she says.

So, SheLift was born. This month marks the nonprofit's first anniversary. SheLift is about using outdoor activities and mentorship to empower young women who need confidence and guidance at critical ages.

Only ET was on set for a photo shoot celebrating the anniversary. Herron enlisted fellow Bachelor Nation alumni Becca Tilley, Amanda Stanton, Ashley Iaconetti and Ali Fedotowsky, along with several women and girls who are part of SheLift, to be photographed in the organization's signature T-shirts. Photographer Brandon Kidd and celebrity makeup artist Emma Willis were also on hand. The shirts read, "Maybe You Literally Can Even," a play off of the now-popular phrase, "I can't even." Bachelor executive producer Elan Gale actually came up with the wording.

EXCLUSIVE: This 'Bachelor' Executive Producer Wrote a Book To Change the Way You See the World

"The idea is to stop saying 'I can't' and start saying 'I can,'" Herron says. "Especially when you're working with girls with limb differences and physical differences. It's ... a more positive outlook. Maybe you literally can climb a mountain or ride a bike, and pushing girls to try things they've never done before."

Herron got support from Chris Harrison and dozens of Bachelor Nation alumni for the organization's first campaign, which raised over $30,000. Her goal this year is to top that, and to send SheLift girls and their mothers on a ski retreat, where they'll learn to ski and connect with other girls and women like them.

"Sarah has taken her platform from The Bachelor and BIP and is doing something for girls who have really grown up the way she did, which is a little bit different," Iaconetti tells ET. "Now she's making everybody feel great about themselves and ... it's amazing!"



Stanton adds, "Having two daughters and just knowing how important it is to feel confident and comfortable in your own skin, that's why I really love what Sarah's doing."

Anyone can support SheLift by buying a T-shirt, a mug or more at SheLift.org. Herron's next money-raising effort? She plans to take advantage of all those good-looking Bachelor Nation guys!

"I really want to do Hot Guys Supporting SheLift!" she says. "You don't have to be a woman to support women ... [we'll] get a bunch of hot guys in these T-shirts."'

b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a party! Jimmy Fallon kicked off Saturday Night Live on April 15 with an epic flash mob featuring Harry Styles dancing to the late David Bowie\xe2\x80\x98s \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s Dance.\xe2\x80\x9d

The Tonight Show host, 42, returned to host the NBC late-night sketch comedy show for the first time since 2013 to celebrate the first-ever episode that aired live from coast to coast. \xe2\x80\x9cTonight is bigger than a show,\xe2\x80\x9d he said during his opening monologue. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a party!\xe2\x80\x9d

The royal family gathered this morning for a traditional Easter Sunday Service - at the chapel where Meghan Markle and Prince Harry will marry on May 19th.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, expecting their third child within weeks, broke usual protocol by arriving after the Queen at the Easter Mattins Service at St George's Chapel in Windsor.

The couple eschewed the downhill walk and took a royal car to the entrance, arriving several minutes after the Queen, who also arrived by car and was travelling without the Duke of Edinburgh, 96, who did not attend the service.

Although Meghan and Harry also chose not to appear at the chapel where they'll tie the knot next month; the Queen, dressed in cerise, was joined by Princess Anne, Prince Andrew and Prince Edward, with Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie, Peter Phillips and Zara Tindall all also in attendance for the seasonal service.

Arriving without husband Mike Tindall and daughter Mia Grace, Zara did take the short downhill walk, showing off her blossoming bump in a blue bespoke S\xc3\xa9raphine coat and hat by Jane Taylor as she chatted with Princess Beatrice, her sister Eugenie and husband-to-be Jack Brooksbank at the chapel's entrance.

Expected to give birth at the Lindo Wing at London's St Mary's Hospital in Paddington sometime this month or in early May, the Duchess looked in fine form as she joined other members of the royal family for the annual Easter service

And Zara's blooming too! The 36-year-old, who attended without husband Mike and daughter Mia Rose, wore a bright blue coat with her own bump clearly visible as she chats to Princess Beatrice. Right: Zara appears to be keeping a close eye on the pavement as she heads to St George's Chapel

The Queen leads her family from the seasonal service at St George's Chapel in Windsor this morning, with the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge following closely behind

It is Spring, honest! Hundreds of well-wishers lined the streets to catch a glimpse of the royals together. The Queen, in a striking cerise pink coat and floral dress, smiles as she accepts a bouquet of beautiful flowers from two little girls attending the Easter Mattins service

Prince William is seen smiling behind his grandmother as he watches her accept the pretty posy from the girls, both dressed in floral outfits

With Prince Philip thought to be nursing a sore hip at home, the Queen attended on her own but clearly enjoyed spending time with her family

The Dean of Windsor, David Conner, led the service, attended by the royal family every year, and strolled by the side of the Queen as she made her way out of the chapel

Despite the inclement weather, the royals opted for spring colour, with Princess Anne (far right) sporting a co-ordinated turquoise blue number. Meanwhile Princess Eugenie mirrored her grandmother's pink, with a cerise cocktail hat London based milliner Juliette Botterill

Hundreds of well-wishers lined the entrance to the Windsor Castle estate hoping for a glimpse of the royals on their annual spring outing.

Wearing a smart-looking chocolate-brown coat, Kate, 36, who is due to give birth to her third child in London in a matter of weeks, looked comfortable and relaxed as she was greeted at the chapel with Prince William by her side. The couple left their two children, George, four and Charlotte, two, at home.

Despite being eight months' pregnant, the Duchess has yet to park her favourite heels and finished off her smart look with a pair of towering caramel-hued shoes and matching clutch purse.

While the Queen attended the event without Prince Philip, it is not thought his absence is due to a serious health problem, the Duke was spotted driving around the grounds of the Windsor Estate last week.

Awaiting the arrival of the Queen to lead the family into the Easter service, Princess Beatrice, wearing a Suzannah coat, shared a joke with Zara, sister Eugenie and boyfriend Jack Brooksbank

The Queen greets the younger royals, including Peter Phillips and his wife Autumn (fourth from left), as she makes her way into the Easter Mattins church service this morning

And Kate wasn't the only one showing off her bump; Zara Tindall looked radiant in bright blue, with her ever blossoming bump clearly on display.

Princess Anne, accompanied by husband Vice Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence, were among the first to make the journey down the hill to the religious venue.

The Queen receives a royal salute from an attending policeman as she makes her way into the regal chapel in the grounds of Windsor Castle - as Princess Anne and Princess Eugenie look on

Sophie Wessex looked chic in a navy wrap-around coat and dramatic fascinator as she walked alongside Lady Louise Windsor, who opted for an aubergine-coloured ensemble.

Meanwhile, the wedding of the year continues to take shape; it was officially announced this morning by Kensington Palace that Philippa Craddock has been chosen to decorate the chapel on Harry and Meghan's big day next month.

The floral designer, who started her business nine years ago, has a list of high-profile clients, including British Vogue, Hampton Court Palace and the V&A. She has also provided her services for Kensington Palace before.

And the flowers and plants will be locally-sourced, with many coming the gardens and parkland of The Crown Estate and Windsor Great Park."

b'It\xe2\x80\x99s that time again!

Thursday, April 13

Upon arrival, Mitchell posed for photos with her stylists, Marie-Lou and Chloe Bartoli. Sunday, April 16

b'When \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d premiered in April 2012, it was almost all that the TV aficionado community could talk about, and it made a giant splash in pop culture, too. Nearly everyone had a strong take on the show Lena Dunham created. Below is Part 2 of Variety\xe2\x80\x99s TV critics\xe2\x80\x99 reflections on the show\xe2\x80\x99s legacy and impact \xe2\x80\x94 and why they\xe2\x80\x99re both happy and sad that the story of Hannah Horvath and her friends is wrapping up. (Part 1, from before the finale aired, is here, and a post-finale talk with executive producers Jenni Konner and Lena Dunham is here.)

Sonia Saraiya: Well, that was pretty perfect. I mean, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t, but in its insular, domestic sphere, harsh reality, \xe2\x80\x9cLatching\xe2\x80\x9d is where this whole season was trending, and such a fitting counterpoint to a similarly insular but much more self-aggrandizing premiere episode of \xe2\x80\x9cGirls.\xe2\x80\x9d I appreciate that instead of being about transformation, for any of the characters, the finale emphasizes resilience \xe2\x80\x94 that problems arise, and our predictable anxieties will flare up, but you can get better at bouncing back.

Furthermore \xe2\x80\x94 I have never felt fully onboard with Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s pregnancy as a plot point, and I appreciated learning that she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t fully onboard with it, either. That narrative about being a new mother sounds like it may have come from Jenni Konner, who co-wrote and directed this episode, who talks about childrearing in interviews (including in a post-finale Q&A with Variety). Glimpsing a bit of \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d famously raw and unflinching lens directed at child-rearing is pretty satisfying.

But really, what got me is that Tracy Chapman\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cFast Car\xe2\x80\x9d was stitched \xe2\x80\x94 thematically and melodically \xe2\x80\x94 through the episode. It\xe2\x80\x99s almost not fair, because that song is wrenching enough to do a lot of emotional heavy lifting on its own. But its circularity about running away, growing up, finding home, and being someone must feel especially relevant when you\xe2\x80\x99re a single mom in a house in the woods, just one car trip away from running away. In the premiere of \xe2\x80\x9cGirls,\xe2\x80\x9d Hannah asks her own parents for money; in the finale, she has to assume the mantle of grown-up, even though she\xe2\x80\x99s scared s\xe2\x80\x93itless, mostly because someone has to do it, and she can\xe2\x80\x99t quit now. But is this what she wanted? Is she happy? Or is her settled contentment at the end, once Grover has finally started breastfeeding, about as good as it gets in this life? \xe2\x80\x9cFast Car\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have easy answers, and I liked that \xe2\x80\x9cLatching\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\xe2\x80\x99t either.

Maureen Ryan: Oh \xe2\x80\x9cGirls,\xe2\x80\x9d you did the most \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d thing possible: After loving most of the lyrical and emotionally acute final season, I spent a good chunk of the finale wanting to scream and fending off a migraine. For me, the combative self-absorption of the characters just felt overly familiar and the setting a little too claustrophobic, and for the first two-thirds of the episode, a lot of the post-birth story played out in ways that I found frustrating rather than illuminating. I see where you\xe2\x80\x99re coming from, and the last few minutes were sweet and memorable, but in the main, I found this particular variety of \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d episode \xe2\x80\x94 argumentative and somewhat predictable \xe2\x80\x94 more off-putting than most. So here we are, having one more critical argument about \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 yay?

The thing is, many different TV shows have hauled out the difficulties of parenting a newborn to manufacture drama or conflict, so the topics on display and the treatments of them just felt overly familiar to me. And perhaps Marnie\xe2\x80\x99s oblivious self-absorption was meant to be funny, but we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen that so many times before, and given the stakes \xe2\x80\x94 i.e., the life and health of a baby \xe2\x80\x94 her condescending selfishness really grated on me throughout much of the final half-hour. This being \xe2\x80\x9cGirls,\xe2\x80\x9d perhaps her behavior was meant to annoy, but that\xe2\x80\x99s a flavor that can get old fast.

It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t until the great Becky Ann Baker showed up to school everybody that I could actually begin to find a few shreds of enjoyment in the finale. The upside is, all the yelling and crying and immaturity made me more than OK than with the fact that this show \xe2\x80\x94 which I have often loved, especially this season \xe2\x80\x94 is ending. Good luck, little Grover. (She really named her kid Grover? Hannah. You did not have to do that. Sigh.)

Saraiya: How funny that you are positive about the show, but not about the finale, while I am almost vice-versa. I liked \xe2\x80\x9cLatching,\xe2\x80\x9d though I admit that I have no idea what to make of the fact that Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s son is a brown baby \xe2\x80\x94 and will grow up to be a man of color. With this show\xe2\x80\x99s relationship to racial dynamics, something about this feels strangely superficial. Of course, at this point, \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d is damned if it does, and damned if it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x94 but isn\xe2\x80\x99t it a bit odd that It\xe2\x80\x99s never discussed or dealt with, it\xe2\x80\x99s just, oh yeah, Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s having a brown baby? The show\xe2\x80\x99s deep-seated discomfort with engaging with race never disappeared, despite six seasons of us talking about it.

In Part 1, you wrote that you always found \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d to be sincere. That struck me while watching the finale and pondering this baby, because I was so often frustrated that the show wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sincere with its setups \xe2\x80\x94 there was this surreality or fantasy-level to the characters\xe2\x80\x99 lives that made them more ciphers than characters. Even in this final season, which has been one of the most grounded, I read this long piece about how Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s salaried-with-benefits teaching job at a cushy lib arts school upstate is essentially impossible. Maybe what you were saying is that the show always meant well \xe2\x80\x94 but even that, I\xe2\x80\x99m not always so sure about. I\xe2\x80\x99m not saying I\xe2\x80\x99m ascribing evil motives to the show either. But like, I think sometimes the show was going for the best joke, or the most interesting denouement, not the one it felt the most strongly about.

In its defense, though, I think \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d was as much about Dunham and co. making characters out of the idiosyncrasies and silliness that they themselves were experiencing in the high creative echelons of contemporary hipsterdom. Hannah the writer, Ray the failed artist, Adam the actor, Marnie the \xe2\x80\x9cmusician,\xe2\x80\x9d Shosh the publicist, Jessa from rehab \xe2\x80\x94 and on, and on. That person you know who moved upstate to have a kid on her own. That girl who got engaged two weeks after meeting someone and seems very happy. The one whose marriage fell apart and is now having some obscure experience of personal growth in another state. We don\xe2\x80\x99t have tell-all novels, a la Jay McInerney or Bret Easton Ellis, about the New York arty media scene anymore: now we have shows like \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d to deliver second- or thirdhand gossip.

This cements one of my long-held feelings about the show, which is that more than being aimed at millennials, it was a show about millennials for millennials\xe2\x80\x99 parents. Not you, Mo, you proud Gen X-er, but those homeowning HBO subscribers who want to ask what their kids are doing but maybe don\xe2\x80\x99t feel so comfortable asking about \xe2\x80\x9ccrack-cidents\xe2\x80\x9d on the phone. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it\xe2\x80\x99s insignificant that this series has been as much about Becky Ann Baker\xe2\x80\x99s transformation, as Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s mom, as it has been about Hannah herself. (She was just fantastic in the finale.)

Ryan: I think you\xe2\x80\x99re onto something there. I once wrote a long piece about the similarities between Liz Phair and Lena Dunham (who both went to Oberlin, and who both were lionized and torn apart in equal measure for their creative exploits \xe2\x80\x94 20 years apart). We touched on this briefly in Part 1 of our dialogue, this idea of voyeurism: I would bet most HBO subscribers have never lived in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, but they want a window into that world, just like they want to know, on Sunday nights, what\xe2\x80\x99s up in the realm of dragons and Lannisters. You\xe2\x80\x99re so right about this being the Jay McInerney or Tama Janowitz novel of its time. Who has the time to read the hot new novelist\xe2\x80\x99s take on what the cool people are doing in NYC? But we can watch this show and feel at least partially informed about what the Youngs are up to.

I recall that somewhat early in the show\xe2\x80\x99s run, a bunch of stories were published on the topic of how a goodly number of middle-aged male HBO subscribers watched \xe2\x80\x9cGirls.\xe2\x80\x9d Well, why wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t they? Not only would it make all those tuition-paying dads feel like they knew what was up in their kids\xe2\x80\x99 lives, \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d contended with the issues surrounding masculinity and intimacy that a lot of other prestige shows explore, but with a lot fewer murders and brothels.

Hannah grappled with a lot of things \xe2\x80\x94 her narcissism, her difficulty in sustaining jobs and relationships, her parents\xe2\x80\x99 breakup, and now, this season, an unexpected pregnancy. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve been thinking a lot about that the fact that a huge throughline of the show has concerned the reality that the men in Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s life were often both more and less than she could handle, and she was never quite sure what to do about that. (As Hannah herself notes, Grover was just the latest in a long list of males with whom she had difficulties, though he was probably also the cutest. And not to sidestep the race thing, but it\xe2\x80\x99s really strange to me that Hannah wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t address the fact that she is parenting a non-white boy. You\xe2\x80\x99d think that would be the exact sort of thing she\xe2\x80\x99d monologue about, and I can definitely see why you felt that aspect of the story felt tacked-on.)

But speaking of men in general, I think a lot of women watching could relate to the issues that Hannah and all the other women contended with when it came to the guys in their lives. Weirdly enough, there were a lot of moments in which the men felt as though they were more dimensionalized than the women \xe2\x80\x94 in a show called \xe2\x80\x9cGirls.\xe2\x80\x9d It was one more conundrum to contend with, I suppose.

That said, I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel all that cheated about who grew most or least, given that, as you say, for most of the characters on the show, they didn\xe2\x80\x99t grow a ton. As was the case with Don Draper, I think they got better at recognizing and accepting their flaws, and seeing past their own pain and self-absorption and at least attempting altruism on a regular basis (the presence of a helpless baby in your life will often force that kind of accelerated growth on a person). Over time, though they were still spectacularly myopic at times, the show undeniably got better at depicting them sometimes stepping past the landmines that they, in the past, would have embraced in a fairly unthinking way.

Saraiya: This is interesting, because I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have come to this conclusion. I never felt the show was interrogating its men. Adam is a great character, and has really grown on me, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t think the show has ever really investigated what was behind his pent-up rage and desire to humiliate his sexual partners in the first season \xe2\x80\x94 the negging, almost, that characterized his affection for Hannah. I mean, he ended up with Jessa, who two episodes ago admitted she was a sociopath. Ray is a curmudgeon, and the show kind of embraces that; but along the way he\xe2\x80\x99s used Shoshana pretty abominably. Laird is out here still hitting on Hannah. And while Elijah is, again, played very well by Andrew Rannells, I\xe2\x80\x99m not so sure that he\xe2\x80\x99s learned or grown or anything. If \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d is anything, it\xe2\x80\x99s the show of barely perceptible character development.

On the other hand, though, it\xe2\x80\x99s probably significant that Hannah has not a girl baby but a boy \xe2\x80\x94 Grover, the name for the cutest boy muppet. And throughout the finale, Hannah makes these funny comments like \xe2\x80\x9cMen are disgusting!\xe2\x80\x9d for no real reason. Maybe for Dunham, \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d was partly an effort to redeem men. It seems she may have succeeded.

Ryan: You may be right \xe2\x80\x94 along with the show, I may not have investigated the motivations and actions of the male characters as much as I could have. I think that might be partly for a defensible reason \xe2\x80\x94 damn, this cast was so good. It was hard not to be forgiving (possibly too forgiving) when the characters were this unpredictable and often hilarious in their oddity and messy, fascinating humanity. Alex Karpovsky, Adam Driver, Andrew Rannells and Peter Scolari were just so fun to watch, no matter how weak or selfish or weird their characters were, and Chris O\xe2\x80\x99Dowd saying \xe2\x80\x9cThat was my Humie\xe2\x80\x9d in his epic final fight with Jessa ranks in my Top 5 \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d lines ever. Elijah was often the comic relief, but Rannells could turn on a dime and almost make me cry, even when he was just running lines in a department store.

Would you agree that the members of the cast \xe2\x80\x94 particularly the core four women \xe2\x80\x94 have become better actors, in some cases shockingly so, since the show began? It\xe2\x80\x99s not that I think anyone was bad back in 2012, but there were moments when I wondered about the range and versatility of some of the performers. The assurance that they have now, and the wide array of emotions that they can lock into, I find, is truly remarkable. Dunham in particular has been able to work in small gestures and very subtle emotional shades this season. She\xe2\x80\x99s really been exceptional. And it didn\xe2\x80\x99t surprise me that Allison Williams was so good in \xe2\x80\x9cGet Out\xe2\x80\x9d because she\xe2\x80\x99s grown tremendously on \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d in the last few years. Am I wrong about that?

Saraiya: Oh, absolutely. Dunham in particular has become a much stronger actress. Her scene with Jemima Kirke in the penultimate episode, \xe2\x80\x9cGoodbye Tour,\xe2\x80\x9d is striking for just how emotive both are after spending so many seasons playing robotic caricatures. I\xe2\x80\x99m inclined to think that Williams\xe2\x80\x99 performance has stayed the same, but the writers\xe2\x80\x99 sense of irony towards her has heightened (and in \xe2\x80\x9cGet Out,\xe2\x80\x9d she is entirely manufactured, which of course makes perfect sense). The show has also been characterized by performers that were already great, right from the start: Becky Ann Baker, Andrew Rannells, Adam Driver, Zosia Mamet, and Alex Karpovsky (who in some episodes stole the show from Dunham).

Ryan: Agreed. To wrap things up, here\xe2\x80\x99s the greatest compliment I can pay any show, and I think \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d certainly merits it: I know I\xe2\x80\x99ll spend time thinking about what all these men and women are up to, even though I won\xe2\x80\x99t get to check in on their lives and loves and aspirations any time soon. How will they get on? Will they find ways to support each other, even as they stumble over the bigger obstacles and frustrations life is likely to throw at them in the next couple of decades? If there is a reunion movie several years from now, I\xe2\x80\x99d eagerly watch that (and of course it\xe2\x80\x99s no sure thing that this great cast, all of whom deserve to go on to bigger and better things, will not too busy to be reassembled). What\xe2\x80\x99s great is that I honestly can\xe2\x80\x99t fully picture the trajectory of each character, though I like to imagine a future in which Ray is the mayor of New York, or at least the crankiest dad in Brooklyn.

These characters frustrated me, they entertained me, they shook up what was possible on television. They made me re-examine my assumptions and they prompted some of the best conversations I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever had about this medium that we love. Hannah Horvath, you forced me to think harder and to dig deeper, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know if I fully got what \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d was going for all the time, but I\xe2\x80\x99m truly grateful for the provocations and the laughs and the unpredictable ride.

I can easily picture Grover reminiscing about his mom 20 years from now, when he\xe2\x80\x99s sitting on the lawn of some well-regarded liberal arts college.

\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s a lot,\xe2\x80\x9d he\xe2\x80\x99ll probably say, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it was an adventure every day.\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Dakota Meyer accused Bristol Palin of keeping him from seeing his daughter Sailor and claimed she left him a week before their wedding in a long, explosive social media post on Wednesday.

The former Marine, 30, took to Instagram in the morning to share details of his past relationship with Bristol, 27, including their first planned wedding, which they called off before the birth of their first child together.

Bristol and Dakota were first set to tie the knot in May 2015 in Dakota's home state of Kentucky, but that wedding was called off. They had their daughter Sailor in December 2015 and married in June 2016 in a surprise ceremony.

Message: Dakota Meyer, 30, shared this photo of himself with his daughter Sailor, two, on Wednesday while speaking out against his ex-wife Bristol Palin, 27

The pair are now parents to Sailor, two, and Atlee, one. Bristol also has a nine-year-old son, Tripp, with her ex Levi Johnston, 28.

In his Instagram post, Dakota offered more details about the events that led to the cancellation of that first wedding and its aftermath. The pair had gotten engaged during a Rascal Flatts concert in Las Vegas in early 2015.

Dakota said on Wednesday that he had chosen to open up in order to respond to an exchange Bristol had on the Teen Mom Instagram account.

The pair are currently appearing on the new season of Teen Mom OG. While they have officially divorced, the show started filming while they were still together, and thus documents the dissolution of their marriage.

Dakota began his post, which featured a photo of him holding Sailor in his arms, by saying Bristol 'got pregnant right after [their] engagement'.

'We planned a wedding with our families and friends and Bristol decided to leave me a week prior,' he added. 'I spoke with her family every month and made it clear I would be the father of my child.

'I reached out to her before Sailor was born and asked what the plan was to co-parent. She told me to go through the courts to establish paternity.'

Opening up: The former Marine took to Instagram Stories to share more thoughts about his divorce from Bristol and the circumstances of their split

Dakota opened up about the circumstances of Sailor's birth, adding: 'I wasn't invited to the birth and found out my child was born on Twitter \xe2\x80\x94 can you imagine being a dad and not being allowed to be at your child's birth?'

He added about Bristol: 'She denied my paternity until it could be proven, at which point Sailor was born. For Bristol to state that Sailor didn't have a dad is laughable \xe2\x80\x94 what really happened is Bristol kept our daughter from having a father present at birth and until the courts ruled that I was her father.

'I can promise you this, Sailor and Atlee always had a dad, and always will have a dad.'

Back when Bristol announced her pregnancy, a month after her and Dakota's canceled wedding, she initially didn't disclose whether the former Marine was the father of her child.

In January 2016, DailyMail.com revealed exclusively that Dakota was being forced to take a paternity test in an increasingly bitter battle over custody of Sailor.

Dakota also took to Instagram Stories to answer questions from his viewers regarding his relationship with Bristol and their split.

He said he did file for divorce from his wife, saying he only did so after she told him she wanted a divorce and had 'already met with an attorney first'.

Dakota acknowledged his PTSD and anxiety, which Bristol has cited as important factors in their split, adding: 'but I wasn't married to anyone perfect'.

Family: The father said he has a 'week on, week off' custody arrangement with Bristol and advised other people to cherish their loved ones

Bristol Palin and Dakota Meyer's relationship: a timeline Bristol and Dakota met in 2014 during the filming of Sarah Palin's Sportsman Channel show Amazing America. The pair got engaged during a Rascal Flatts concert in Las Vegas in early 2015. Bristol and Dakota (pictured in an archive Instagram shot) met in 2014 during the filming of Sarah Palin's Sportsman Channel show Amazing America They planned a wedding in Dakota's home state of Kentucky, which was called off at the last minute in May 2015. Bristol and Dakota's first daughter together, Sailor, now two, was born in December 2015. In early 2016, it was revealed that Dakota was being asked to take a paternity test as part of a bitter battle over custody of Sailor. Dakota and Bristol tied the knot in June 2016. In December of that year, Bristol, who also has a nine-year-old son called Tripp with her ex Levi Johnston, 28, announced she was expecting her third child \xe2\x80\x94 her second with Dakota. She gave birth to their daughter Atlee, now one, in May 2017. It emerged in February this year that Dakota had filed for divorce. Bristol confirmed in August that the proceedings had been finalized. Advertisement

When one Instagram user asked Dakota when he knew enough was enough, he replied: 'I knew enough was enough when I would hear her talk to her family in front of me and say "I can't believe I wasted three years with a mother f***er like this.'

Another person asked Dakota whether he ever feared he might hurt someone while having a PTSD episode, to which he said: 'That's such a great question. No, absolutely not. I've never put my hands on Bristol. I've never hurt Bristol. I've never said anything to Bristol she hasn't said to me, so let's clarify that.'

The father also revealed that he has a 'week on, week off' custody arrangement with Bristol and admitted that he does have a nanny, adding 'but I also have a job hahaha'.

Bristol and Dakota, who met in 2014 during the filming of Sarah Palin's Sportsman Channel show Amazing America, have publicly discussed their relationship on social media and in interviews recently amid their appearance on Teen Mom OG.

On Monday evening, Bristol took to her Instagram Story to react to the latest episode of the MTV show. She then deleted the many messages she had posted in relation to the show from her Story, leaving only a photo of herself tuning into the program with her son Tripp at her side.

Monday's episode saw Dakota warning viewers about being with someone who '[doesn't] want to be there for you' or is 'not strong enough', while Bristol said her two-year marriage was 'at a breaking point' after Dakota's PTSD rendered him anxious and sleep-deprived.

Speaking out: On Monday, Dakota did another Instagram Q&A, and this time spoke out to reiterate that he will not be getting married again, while sharing a rather imposing photo

Speaking out: Bristol called 'BS' on her ex-husband on Monday evening while watching a Teen Mom OG segment documenting the dissolution of their marriage

While it's unclear which specific segment prompted Bristol to react to the footage on her Instagram Story, she shared images of Dakota during the episode with the words 'K... kind of BS' written over the footage.

She then highlighted the fact that Dakota was the one who filed for divorce, and said that she only 'put [her] foot down' and decided the pair should go through with the breakup because she thought it would be best for her children.

On her Instagram Story, Bristol shared a message from a person accusing her of 'leaving your husband when he needs you the most', telling Bristol her behavior is 'sickening'.

Bristol replied by saying: 'Let's just get a few facts straight' before posting a series of updates. In the first, she called Dakota an 'incredible father' and reminded her Instagram followers that they only see '.002' of her and Dakota's lives on the show.

'Like Dakota has said multiple times on IG and in interviews... Our marriage was over WAY BEFORE TMOG,' she added.

Opening up: Bristol highlighted the fact that Dakota was the one who filed for divorce and expressed her respect for his service as a Marine

Bristol then said Dakota moved out of the family home 'more times than [she] would ever like to admit'.

'He got an attorney. He filed for divorce,' she added. 'Wait, did you read that? He filed for divorce. And he kept coming and going based on what he thought was best.

'I did not ask for a divorce, but I did look at my children, and knew the marriage was NOT what was best for them. Just because the picture you see painted is ME finally putting my foot down, to end the back and forth, does NOT mean I didn't give my marriage and Dakota, everything I had in me.'

Bristol added that she respects Dakota's service as a former Marine, and that she 's 'thankful' her daughters have him as a father.'

'I never "gave up" on Dakota, or on our family. I know in my heart I did everything I could,' she wrote, before stating that she believes the divorce will enable her children to grow up in a 'much happier' environment.

She also credited Dakota for doing everything he could to try and save his marriage before finally calling it quits.

'I do want what's best for Dakota and know that in my heart,' she wrote.

Bristol watched the episode with Tripp by her side, thought she said he wouldn't be tuning into the show and shared a photo of her son wearing large headphones.

Tripp, who was recently eliminated from Dancing With The Stars: Juniors, appeared to be tucking into a frozen yogurt bar along with his mother, who had her glasses on to follow the program.

Duo: Bristol watched Teen Mom with her son Tripp, nine, at her side, though he was wearing large headphones and was apparently not tuning into the program

Family: Bristol shared a couple of photos of Sailor, two, and Atlee, one, and said she was missing them 'so much it hurts' as the two little girls were away

The mother also said on her Instagram Story that she was missing her two daughters 'so much it hurts' and that she would be apart from them for 'six more days'.

She posted two photos of Sailor and Atlee cuddling together, writing the word 'perfection' on top of one of the photos.

Earlier this month, Dakota discussed his breakup from Bristol in a new interview with People, detailing the moment that he knew their relationship was over.

Bristol and Dakota split earlier this year, with Bristol confirming in August that the proceedings had been finalized.

'This relationship was done way before Teen Mom OG,' Dakota told People.

The former Marine then joked that he knew the relationship was over 'the day after we got married', according to People.

'Our relationship has had struggles from day one, I think we tried our best,' he added. 'I can definitely say that I tried in this relationship.'

Marriage woes: On Monday's episode of Teen Mom OG, Bristol opened up about the difficulties she was facing in her marriage at the time, along with Dakota

On Monday's episode of Teen Mom OG, Bristol opened up about the difficulties she was facing in her marriage at the time, saying: 'It's draining\xe2\x80\xa6 I live my life on complete eggshells, I think everyone in this house does, even the kids.'

She added: 'I don't like my marriage at all.'

Dakota, meanwhile, saw things differently.

'I love Bristol but you can only do that for so long and not get it back,' he said.

'If someone tells you they don't want to be there for you, or that they're not strong enough to be there for you, don't be an idiot like me and not believe them,' he warned.

'It's been something that's been hard for me to accept, it breaks my heart, I know that I'm a good human being, I also know that I want a home where I've got support,' Dakota added.

'I don't want to have to go to other people's houses to get support,' he continued sadly.

'I was a single mom for a long time but now, being married, I'm more lonely now than I've ever been,' said Bristol, who decided they should split.

b'Prince Harry has disclosed that he sought counselling after enduring two years of \xe2\x80\x9ctotal chaos\xe2\x80\x9d while still struggling in his late twenties to come to terms with the death of his mother.

The Prince says in an interview with The Telegraph that he \xe2\x80\x9cshut down all his emotions\xe2\x80\x9d for almost two decades after losing his mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, despite his brother, Prince William, trying to persuade him to seek help.

Disclosing that he has spoken to a professional about his mental health, he describes how he only began to address his grief when he was 28 after feeling \xe2\x80\x9con the verge of punching someone\xe2\x80\x9d and facing anxiety during royal engagements.'

b"Jennifer Lopez and Alex Rodriguez heat up the dance floor in the Dominican Republic By: Hayley Bradbrook

It looks like Jennifer Lopez has found herself a new dancing partner. The mother of two was spotted heating up the dance floor with her boyfriend Alex Rodriguez while on vacation in the Dominican Republic on Sunday (Apr. 16).

#afterparty #jlo #arod #altosdechavon #casadecampos #dominicanrepublic #onesir#nicksilva #the_concept A post shared by Miami Luxury Realtor (@susydunand) on Apr 16, 2017 at 4:47pm PDT

Jennifer isn\xe2\x80\x99t letting her busy schedule stand in the way of love. b'Hoda Kotb returned to her second home Monday morning.

Kotb joined Savannah Guthrie and Matt Lauer on "Today" for the first time since announcing on Feb. 21 that she had adopted a daughter, Haley Joy Kotb.

"It's everything," she said of motherhood. Kotb added that she would regularly tune in to see her colleagues work when she was on maternity leave. "I saw everybody," she said, "and I'm blubbering like a baby."

Fans lined Rockefeller Plaza to herald Hoda's return.

Admitting she'd "been a mess" all morning, Kotb said she was nervous to be back on camera. "I'm scared to be sitting here," she shared. "I'm a little afraid that I might explode into tears."

Lauer lightened the mood, joking, "I thought it was 'cause you were miserable being back and you just broke down in tears, but it's just all of the emotions of the last two and a half months."

Though they had visited her at home, Guthrie and Lauer were glad to see Kotb back at work in Studio 1A.

"I'm feeling great. I don't think I've ever been this happy," Kotb said, reaching for a box of tissues to dry her eyes. After regaining her composure, the 52-year-old fourth-hour "Today" co-host said, "I'm going to get professional! OK, I'm ready."

Kotb then got back to business. Six minutes later, Al Roker appeared via satellite from Washington, D.C., where he was reporting on the 139th annual Easter Egg Roll at the White House. "Mwah! I miss you," the weatherman said. "I'll bring you back some eggs for Haley Joy."

After receiving a "hug chain" from fans, Kotb admitted it was "a little hard" saying goodbye to her daughter before work.

"But, I have to tell you, when I walked in, there's something about looking into the eyes of people who are just happy for you that makes me explode, which is why I was doing that with all of you guys and everyone who is out here," she said with a big smile. "I'm blessed to be able to have this great family and a little girl at home waiting for me."

Today Show Family Album

At 8:10 a.m., Kotb opened up about her adoption journey and revealed how motherhood has changed her.

"You think that by a certain stage in your life, I've had every experience that I've had, and then all of a sudden she shows up," the journalist said. "I felt like in my life, I've had joy beyond what I could have imagined, but this is beyond a dream. Like, you had your dreams--and then this. I never believed in love at first sight until now."

Kotb joked that Haley "probably thinks it's raining in her nursery, because I'm always looking at her and crying on her."

Haley is the missing puzzle piece, she added. "When they first handed me Haley, I was scared to hold her, and when they first put her in my arms, it was a perfect fit."

The Origins of Hoda Kotb and Kathie Lee Gifford's Friendship

Before she decided to become a parent, Hoda feared it might be "too late," as she'd already been through cancer and a divorce. "You just think, 'OK, I don't get everything and it's OK.'"

After a while, though, she began to wonder, "Why not me?" With her mind made up, she talked it over with her boyfriend, Joel "Boots" Schiffman.

"I said to Joel, I want to ask you something, and this is a big deal. I want you to think about it. I don't want you to answer right away.' I said, 'I would like to explore adoption with you,'" Kotb said. "He said, 'I don't need a minute. I'm in.'"

Haley Joy is better than she ever envisioned. "When I look at her I see forever. I see past me," Kotb gushed as tears streamed down her cheeks. "I see the future, which I guess I never saw."

"I want her to know she is loved by me, by my family and by everyone who's held her," Kotb said at the end of the segment. "I don't think she's going to know what to do with all the love."

Back in the studio, Kotb told Dylan Dreyer, Lauer and Guthrie, "She is something. She's something. She's changed everything about me. Everything. Like, every single thing about me."

Lauer, 59, added, "Joel is the perfect partner for this. He is such a wonderful, warm, great guy."

"Anyway, I have baby!" Kotb said, trying to keep the tears at bay again. "I have a baby! Hello! Thank you for making me feel so good. Coming back has been amazing. Thanks for loving me."

When the 10:00 a.m. hour with Kathie Lee Gifford began, Kotb received a gift basket that included books, a lullaby album and a sash. Gofford cheered Kotb and laughed, "Joel's daughter is finally graduating college and now he's got a brand new baby."

Kotb joked, "Here we go again!"

She again became emotional while discussing this new chapter of her life.

"I've loved her, I think, my whole life," Kotb said of Haley Joy. "I think since forever." As Kotb wiped away her tears, Gifford said, "She looks like you--she's got a big head and huge feet!"

"I love it," Kotb laughed. "I love her head."

After waiting so long to become a mom, Kotb doesn't want to miss a moment of her baby's life. "I sleep in the room with her so that whenever she starts crying I'm ready. When it's like 6:00 or last wakeup, I walk over and...I look at her and she's hungry and she needs changing. And I go, 'Well, good morning nugget.' She gets a smile: 'Hi.' Just like that," she told Gifford. "I swear to you, if I could live in that moment...you know how you wish moments could last forever?"

Even in her "worst moments" as a mom, Kotb focused on gratitude: "Because I would have begged \xe2\x80\x94 begged \xe2\x80\x94 for a day like this. I would have begged for that kind of day, to have a child. I don't know why I'm crying! I cry over everything! I'm normally not like this. I've become crazy!"

"You can't believe how your heart can feel," Kotb added. "I can't believe it feels this way."

Kotb, who apologized to viewers for "so much baby talk," then told Gifford, "I cannot believe this is my life...By the way, I am taking my time. I am enjoying moments that I know I would have raced through...As I'm doing it, I'm trying to linger, savor...enjoy every moment."

"I didn't know that I could feel that kind of contentment \xe2\x80\x94 just so satisfied with everything," Kotb said around 10:35, adding that she "turned off" her electronic devices to focus on what matters: making memories with her daughter.

"I realized there's so much love to be had," she told Gifford, "and I think sometimes it's smart to block some of the negativity that's out there in the world and realize that your world could be beautiful \xe2\x80\x94 if you keep it tight like that."

(E! and NBC are both members of the NBCUniversal family.)'

b'Charlie Hunnam vows his marriage was terrible.

During an interview with the Associated Press in Las Vegas March 30, the Sons of Anarchy actor recounted his hasty 1999 wedding to actress Katharine Towne, who he had met at a Dawson\xe2\x80\x99s Creek audition. Listen to what he said in the video above!

\xe2\x80\x9cFirst time I was ever in Vegas I got married, which didn\xe2\x80\x99t turn out that well,\xe2\x80\x9d Hunnam, 37, said. \xe2\x80\x9cI had known the girl for three weeks. We had fallen madly in love and it was the first time I had ever been in love.\xe2\x80\x9d

The pair decided to elope before Hunnam, then 18, had to head back home to England. \xe2\x80\x9cWe thought, \xe2\x80\x98What if we never see each other again? Let\xe2\x80\x99s get married and then we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to see each other again even if it\xe2\x80\x99s just to get divorced,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d he recalled. \xe2\x80\x9cSo we came to Vegas, but I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even get a drink so I actually didn\xe2\x80\x99t think I would be able to get married.\xe2\x80\x9d

But anything goes in Sin City. At 2 A.M., Hunnam and Towne said \xe2\x80\x9cI do\xe2\x80\x9d in front of Silver Bell Wedding Chapel\xe2\x80\x99s Reverend RJ Cotton. (They wanted to get married by Elvis but \xe2\x80\x9che left the building,\xe2\x80\x9d joked Hunnam.)

The end result: \xe2\x80\x9cThree terrible years,\xe2\x80\x9d admitted Hunnam, whose divorce was finalized in 2002. \xe2\x80\x9cThree terrible, painful, expensive years. I got the cats at the end of it, so that was good. There was a small victory.\xe2\x80\x9d

He\xe2\x80\x99s since gone on to find success in his 12-year relationship with jewelry designer Morgana McNelis. The pair reside in a $2.76 million Hollywood Hills pad that likely sees a lot of action. After all, The Lost City of Z star recently reveled he stays in shape by having tons of sex, among other activities.

\xe2\x80\x9cI try to do it all. I also try to make love as often as I can. That\xe2\x80\x99s an important part of fitness. There\xe2\x80\x99s no reason you can\xe2\x80\x99t be active at 70. I want to run up mountains at that age,\xe2\x80\x9d Hunnam told Men\xe2\x80\x99s Health. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are supposed to be very active animals. It\xe2\x80\x99s our DNA. Sweating is how I change my oil every day. I just feel happier, more positive, energized, and disciplined if I work out.\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur show\xe2\x80\x99s never been about the traditional, tidy wrap-up.\xe2\x80\x9d

That\xe2\x80\x99s what Lena Dunham had to say to The Daily Beast about why Sunday night\xe2\x80\x99s series finale of Girls focused not on the entire cast, but on only Hannah and Allison Williams\xe2\x80\x99s Marnie raising Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s baby\xe2\x80\x94named Grover!\xe2\x80\x94together in the country.

Now that the show has officially wrapped its groundbreaking, award-winning, zeitgeist-seizing six-season run on HBO, Dunham and Girls\xe2\x80\x99s co-showrunner and executive producer Jenni Konner, who also directed Sunday\xe2\x80\x99s finale, hopped on the phone together to talk about the last episode, the show\xe2\x80\x99s legacy, and baby names. (\xe2\x80\x9cIt like had to be something that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t, like, far-out celebrity baby name, but it also couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a generic name,\xe2\x80\x9d Konner says about the name Grover. \xe2\x80\x9cShe knew he had to be the only one in the class with that name.\xe2\x80\x9d)

The last episode of Girls flashes forward five months to Hannah and Marnie co-parenting Grover together. Hannah is struggling to bond with her son, can\xe2\x80\x99t get him to breastfeed, and is breaking down over the anxiety of it all. Marnie, in her Type A way, picks up all the slack, which overwhelms her to the point that she calls Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s mom, Becky Ann Baker\xe2\x80\x99s Loreen, to come give Hannah a wake-up call.

Amid Hannah ignoring Grover\xe2\x80\x99s crying, napping all day, and wandering the streets with no shoes or pants on\xe2\x80\x94of course\xe2\x80\x94Loreen tells her, \xe2\x80\x9cYou made the choice to have this child, and guess what? It\xe2\x80\x99s the first one you can\xe2\x80\x99t take back.\xe2\x80\x9d

As for the all-important final shot, of which there was much speculation about going in to Sunday night, particularly in terms of what music would play, it\xe2\x80\x99s of Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s reaction after Grover finally latches onto her breast, after which she starts singing Tracy Chapman to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cJenni was like, \xe2\x80\x98I wonder if anyone\xe2\x80\x99s guess is \xe2\x80\x98Fast Car\xe2\x80\x99 lightly mumbled,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Dunham laughs.

So with the finale finally having aired, here\xe2\x80\x99s our conversation with Dunham and Konner about the choices made, why last week\xe2\x80\x99s penultimate episode purposefully felt like more of a series finale, whether they ever considered Hannah having an abortion, and how think piece culture affected the end of the show.

You named the baby Grover.

Jenni and Lena, in unison: We diiiiid!

I imagine there\xe2\x80\x99s a certain amount of pressure in naming Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s baby. Why Grover?

Jenni: Lena literally showed up one day and walked into the writer\xe2\x80\x99s room and was like, \xe2\x80\x9cHis name is Grover.\xe2\x80\x9d And we were all like, \xe2\x80\x9cYeah that sounds about right.\xe2\x80\x9d

Lena: We did not have a baby name list. We were just like, \xe2\x80\x9cThat seems like what she would name her baby.\xe2\x80\x9d

Jenni: It like had to be something that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t, like, far-out celebrity baby name, but it also couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a generic name. She knew he had to be the only one in the class with that name.

I would venture he\xe2\x80\x99ll be the only Grover Horvath.

Lena: It couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be trendy but it also couldn\xe2\x80\x99t freak you out.

Jenni: The truth is that when we shot Riz [Ahmed], we went back to that. That was a little improv on the day where it was, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat if it\xe2\x80\x99s his idea?\xe2\x80\x9d

Lena: Jenni walked into that little funny set we had for his hotel room, and was like, \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s try a version where he says Grover would be a great name for the baby.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s funny, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think we even told Riz that was the baby\xe2\x80\x99s eventual name. Jenni just fed him that line and he did it. I only told him recently that the baby\xe2\x80\x99s name was Grover and he was like, \xe2\x80\x9cShe took my suggestion!?\xe2\x80\x9d

[Jenni cracks up]

Jenni: The great part, too, is that Lena just realized\xe2\x80\x94this wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in our minds when we did it\xe2\x80\x94that she bets he got it from Sesame Street.

Lena: There\xe2\x80\x99s no way that guy knows the name Grover from anything else. He\xe2\x80\x99s definitely not talking about Grover Cleveland.

A lot of people thought last week\xe2\x80\x99s episode could have worked as a series finale in its own right. What was behind the decision to focus the last half-hour on Hannah and the baby?

Jenni: We had a lot of story we wanted to tell. Judd was like, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you make a finale that\xe2\x80\x99s a finale, like a satisfying \xe2\x80\x98here\xe2\x80\x99s where everybody ends up,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d but we didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to skip the part where Hannah becomes a mother. Like, how unfair to spend this whole season wondering what kind of mother Hannah would be and then never show it?

Lena: Also, our show\xe2\x80\x99s never been about the traditional, tidy wrap-up. We wanted to be able to enjoy that beautiful musical montage moment [from last week\xe2\x80\x99s episode] that\xe2\x80\x99s given us chills and so many other people chills. But we\xe2\x80\x99re also ending the way we\xe2\x80\x99ve always ended everything, which is just like without a massive and clean conclusion.

It does feel appropriate.

Lena: We really felt like we got the best of both worlds and it was really fun because Nisha Ganatra, a director we love but had never worked with came and did episode nine and lent a very different feeling to it, and had the vision for the Hannah moving vs. party intercutting. And then Jenni got to come in and do an off-kilter but totally committed version of the energy that our show traditionally has.

Some TV creators have an ending in mind as early as when they pitch a show. At what point did you realize that this is how you wanted the series to end, with Hannah having her baby and confronting motherhood?

Jenni: I have to say Lena\xe2\x80\x99s been talking about it for a long time.

Lena: I said something about it pretty early, I think sometime between seasons one and two. I mean Jenni and I started talking about endings the night we premiered at SXSW. We were at a hotel in Austin, hotel rooms upstairs and downstairs from each other but obviously talking on our cell phones. We basically talked until we fell asleep about what would become of every character, what the rest of her life would look like, how she would die, and I feel like somewhere in that conversation we said something like, \xe2\x80\x9cWho would be the first person to have a baby?\xe2\x80\x9d And we were like, \xe2\x80\x9cMaybe it\xe2\x80\x99s Hannah.\xe2\x80\x9d It always felt oddly natural to us, and it\xe2\x80\x99s really been an interesting litmus test. We\xe2\x80\x99ve gotten some beautiful emails from women who have chosen or not chosen, who have been forced into single motherhood for various reasons.

Jenni: Really moving.

Lena: And I\xe2\x80\x99ve gotten some really moving emails from women who got pregnant and not chosen to have it. Last week I got a donation in my name to Planned Parenthood with a letter from a woman who said she chose to have an abortion, but that watching Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s journey had made her feel more confident in her own decision. And, like, that\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of thing that you can\xe2\x80\x99t believe how lucky you are when you can spur anyone to think or feel that way. Then there\xe2\x80\x99s definitely been the people who have been like, \xe2\x80\x9cThis women could never have a baby, she\xe2\x80\x99s going to drop it on its head, what the hell are you doing?\xe2\x80\x9d Probably one of my favorite lines of Jenni\xe2\x80\x99s of all time is when I said there are a lot of people who would be worse mothers than Hannah, and Jenni said, \xe2\x80\x9cYeah, like anyone on any Showtime show.\xe2\x80\x9d It was a great Showtime inside baseball joke.

I think there were people who were surprised when the pregnancy storyline was introduced that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t used to make a statement about abortion. Was that a route you ever considered?

Jenni: I mean we\xe2\x80\x99ve tackled abortion, you know? It would have been such a weird move, in my opinion, to, this late in our series, write that she gets pregnant and has an abortion. She\xe2\x80\x99s right on that line of it could happen or it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t happen, and the fact that Joshua [Patrick Wilson\xe2\x80\x99s character] assumes it\xe2\x80\x99s going to happen is very offensive to her. I think what\xe2\x80\x99s interesting about the growth of these characters is that the second episode of the show is Jessa\xe2\x80\x99s pregnant and there\xe2\x80\x99s not a conversation for a second whether she would keep it or not.

Lena: Not at all.

Jenni: It\xe2\x80\x99s not in the realm of possibility.

Lena: Mimi Rose had an abortion and we didn\xe2\x80\x99t even know she was pregnant.

Jenni: Now we get to a place where it\xe2\x80\x99s a few years later and it becomes a conversation, and that seemed like a really interesting idea of growth to us.

Lena: Completely. Plus I was like, you can not like our storyline but you certainly can\xe2\x80\x99t come for my and Jenni\xe2\x80\x99s pro-choice bona fides.

The line that lingered with me most from the finale was when Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s mom says, \xe2\x80\x9cYou made the choice to have this child, and guess what? It\xe2\x80\x99s the first one you can\xe2\x80\x99t take back.\xe2\x80\x9d

Jenni: I think that line is what the entire finale is about. Here\xe2\x80\x99s this girl who\xe2\x80\x99s been accused by everyone in the world\xe2\x80\x94in her world, in the world of viewers, everyone\xe2\x80\x94of being narcissistic so constantly. She\xe2\x80\x99s a girl who quits a job she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like and leaves a relationship she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like. This is the first thing she can\xe2\x80\x99t take back. We\xe2\x80\x99re saying to you: this is it. This is Hannah with high stakes. Now we\xe2\x80\x99re showing you high stakes.

Lena: I remember right before I made Tiny Furniture I very spontaneously quit a job as a hostess.

Jenni: Which we see in the movie!

Lena: Yep! My dad yells at me, like, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is so irresponsible. If you had a baby or anyone depending on you, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be allowed to just go around quitting jobs!\xe2\x80\x9d And I remember looking and going, \xe2\x80\x9cYeah! But I don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d It was this moment where I was like, I don\xe2\x80\x99t, and I\xe2\x80\x99m going to keep quitting things as long as I can. I\xe2\x80\x99m gonna take all the naps I want and quit all the things I want. And this is the moment when Hannah can\xe2\x80\x99t take all the naps she wants and quit all the things she wants. She truly can\xe2\x80\x99t anymore.

There was a lot of curiosity about what song would play over the credits of the final episode, to the point that articles were written speculating about it.

Jenni: I know! We\xe2\x80\x99ve been seeing all these articles. I was like, I hope no one turns it off too fast because you can hardly hear the song.

Lena: Jenni was like, \xe2\x80\x9cI wonder if anyone\xe2\x80\x99s guess is \xe2\x80\x98Fast Car\xe2\x80\x99 lightly mumbled.\xe2\x80\x9d

How did you land on \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Fast Car\xe2\x80\x99 lightly mumbled?\xe2\x80\x9d

Jenni: This is a Judd thing. We decided not to use really almost any music through the episode, so that\xe2\x80\x99s scary and unusual for us. I knew I wanted to hear Allison singing \xe2\x80\x9cFast Car.\xe2\x80\x9d That was just a fantasy of mine, so we did it there. We were trying to figure out how to do the end and Judd said, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat if it\xe2\x80\x99s just Hannah kind of mumble-humming \xe2\x80\x98Fast Car\xe2\x80\x99 in this weird way?\xe2\x80\x9d We called her up. She recorded it on her phone, sent it to us, and it was absolute perfection. We didn\xe2\x80\x99t even change it for the final mix.

Do you think the microscope the show has been under throughout its run and the culture of think pieces surrounding it influenced how you wrapped the show up at all?

Jenni: I mean it had to have seeped in, because we\xe2\x80\x99re not made of wood. But I do think that this is an idea that we had so early on that we weren\xe2\x80\x99t in think piece territory quite yet, and the internet bombardment either. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always said I\xe2\x80\x99d rather have people loving or hating than yawning. We\xe2\x80\x99re really lucky that we go that, and especially this season that people cared so much, like with the Matthew Rhys episode, writing so much about it. And caring so much about last week\xe2\x80\x99s penultimate episode. As much as we were not trying to cater to people, it feels really heavenly to have people understand what we\xe2\x80\x99re trying to do and really appreciating it. It\xe2\x80\x99s been a nice thing to go out with so much positivity.

Lena: The thing I was going to say about the think piece aspect is that I think we did a really successful job of in some ways cocooning ourselves. We made really intentional choices to seclude ourselves and we always had our work to return to in this really beautiful, private way. That really sustained me and made it feel possible to make choices outside of what the internet might be demanding. By the way, the internet is such a terrible psycho beast, where they want to tell you what to do but if you actually did what they told you to do, the bullies would then call you a weakling because you did what they told you to do.

We\xe2\x80\x99re talking on Friday evening. How are you spending the airing of the finale Sunday night?

Jenni: We\xe2\x80\x99re in separate cities. Lena and Allison and her parents are going to watch it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I\xe2\x80\x99m going to do. Maybe I\xe2\x80\x99ll watch it with Judd.

Lena: Not being with Jenni is super weird, and I would be on her sofa in two seconds. But we have to be in different cities right now. Being with Allison will be really special and emotional. She\xe2\x80\x99s basically crying already and has already asked what I want to eat, two extremely Allison qualities. I think there will be a lot of texting Jenni pictures of whatever my face is doing.'

b'The 10 best (and five worst) TV series finales of all time

Kelly Lawler | USA TODAY

Show Caption Hide Caption 'The Americans' Keri Russell and Matthew Rhys: Spy vs. Spy "The Americans" stars Keri Russell and Matthew Rhys: What do they love (and hate) about each others' characters?

There's nothing like the anticipation, expectation and dread that surrounds the finale of a beloved TV series.

This year, three long-running shows \xe2\x80\x94 New Girl, The Middle and The Americans \xe2\x80\x94 said goodbye with three satisfying finales. But that's not always the case. Sometimes, no matter how much you love what came before, a series can miss on its last swing, leaving a bitter taste for years to come.

We've ranked the 10 best and five worst of all time, from golden classics (M*A*S*H) to recent travesties (How I Met Your Mother).

Prefer to listen? Our geek culture podcast, The Mothership, debates the best and worst series finales of all time.

Subscribe for free on Apple Podcasts | Stitcher | SoundCloud

The best

1. Six Feet Under (HBO)

Six Feet Under was always about facing our own mortality (it was, after all, about a family-run funeral-home business), and the near-perfect finale faced the great beyond head-on in its excruciatingly beautiful last sequence, which flashed forward to the deaths of all the main characters \xe2\x80\x94 predictable, tragic or absurd. Every series finale that\xe2\x80\x99s used the flash-forward technique owes a great debt to Six Feet.

2. Newhart (CBS)

As twisty and self-referential as modern TV has gotten, no show could possibly pull off a twist as shocking and meta as the finale of Newhart, which is perhaps better remembered than the show itself. After Dick Loudon (Bob Newhart) is hit in the head with a golf ball, the show cuts to Dr. Robert Hartley, Newhart's character from his previous series, The Bob Newhart Show, waking up from a dream in bed with his wife. All eight seasons of Newhart, set in a Vermont inn, were Hartley's dream. Not even Westworld could do better.

3. M*A*S*H (CBS)

In a poignant, emotional and still top-rated finale, the 11-year run of M*A*S*H (eight years longer than the Korean War it depicted) came to an end as Hawkeye Pierce (Alan Alda) and (most of) the rest finally went home. The sometimes dark final episode, which manages one last "war is hell" moment, perfectly captured the spirit of the series.

4. The Mary Tyler Moore Show (CBS)

Just thinking about that loving final hug is enough to make any MTM fan tear up. The finale ended in the sad, inescapable way many jobs in the real world do. The new owner of WJM fired the entire TV newsroom (well, except Ted), and the former co-workers came together to say goodbye. It felt realistic and emotional, just like most of MTM's run.

5. Battlestar Galactica (Syfy)

The finale to the space epic succeeded where Lost failed, finding a way to use the spiritual and divine to answer its mysteries while making a profound statement about the nature of humanity. Sure, some are still angered by the deus ex machina convenience of the messy, benevolent god guiding the humans and cylons alike, but the relationship between creators and their creations was always the central tenet of the series. And even though the humans and the cylons gave up technology to start a simpler life on Earth, the flash forward to modern robotics also emphasized the show's themes: All this has happened before, and will again. So say we all.

6. The Sopranos (HBO)

The only bad thing you can say about The Sopranos finale is that it pushed the saturation of Journey's Don't Stop Believin' to the breaking point in the years that followed. Some fans didn't take to the open-ended, cut-to-black finale of the mobster drama, which didn't reveal whether Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) lived or died, but his life was too nebulous to be resolved so cleanly.

7. The Shield (FX)

Not every series about an anti-hero is interested in comeuppance at the end, but even if it did, no punishment would be as perfect as the one served to Vic Mackey (Michael Chiklis) in the final episode of the police drama. Mackey ends up in his own version of prison, wasting away at an office job, far from the action and adrenaline he craves.

8. Cheers (NBC)

Sam's (Ted Danson) true love was always his bar. The Cheers finale isn't nearly as happy or funny as many sitcoms' exits, but its wistful tone worked for the bittersweet episode. The gang couldn't stay at the bar forever.

9. Breaking Bad (AMC)

Like any figure so tragic and Shakespearean, Walter White (Bryan Cranston) couldn't survive the end of his story. The cancer-ridden chemistry teacher-turned-drug kingpin had finally admitted his malicious acts were purely for pleasure, but was able to at least partially redeem himself by helping Jesse (Aaron Paul), one of the people he hurt the most.

10. The Americans (FX)

Spoiler alert: The Soviet spy series just concluded its six-year run Wednesday, and the emotions are still running high, so maybe in a few years it wouldn't make this list. But the episode, which found Philip (Matthew Rhys) and Elizabeth (Keri Russell) returning to the Soviet Union after the FBI finally figured out they're illegals, was perfectly suited to the series. They left behind their unwitting son, Henry (Keidrich Sellati), and their comrade daughter, Paige (Holly Taylor), leaves them. This is as close to a happy ending as the series could offer, at once surprising and deeply satisfying.

The worst

1. How I Met Your Mother (CBS)

The finale of the long-running young-friends-in-New York sitcom was legendary, for all the wrong reasons. The episode finally introduced Ted (Josh Radnor) to the mother (Cristin Milioti) of his future children and then, in a series of flash-forwards, proceeded to kill her off and have Ted rekindle his relationship with Robin (Cobie Smulders) after she divorced Barney (Neil Patrick Harris). Had the show not proved that Ted and Robin were a bad couple many times over, and had it not set the entire last season at Robin and Barney's wedding, it might have been able to pull off this ending. Instead, it marked a classic example of a series that mapped out a plan from the beginning but shouldn't have stuck to it.

2. Seinfeld (NBC)

That's it? The decision to end the beloved sitcom about a group of New York misanthropes by putting them in jail for being bad Samaritans is now 20 years old, but age hasn't helped it.

3. Lost (ABC)

A show that wove as many mysteries into its fabric as this supernatural drama did was always bound to dissatisfy some with its conclusion, but the easy, schmaltzy way that the series gave everyone a perfect happy ending in the afterlife was the worst choice.

4. Dexter (Showtime)

The serial-killer drama started to decline long before its much-derided finale, but that didn't help soften the blow of Dexter's (Michael C. Hall) bizarre decision to fake his own death and take up life as a somber lumberjack.

5. Charmed (WB)

The witchy series almost came to an end after seven seasons before getting a reprieve for an eighth. But the finale to Season 7 was a far better way for the Halliwell sisters to exit \xe2\x80\x94 leaving their witch lives behind and going undercover with new identities \xe2\x80\x94 than the actual finale, in which the trio won perfect relationships and lived happily ever after. Charmed often subverted fairy-tale tropes, so the fairy-tale ending didn't track.'

b'Hit me, baby, one more time!

If you just did a double take, you're not alone. SI Swimsuit cover model Kate Upton is taking it to the next level in this short preview from her upcoming Lip Sync Battle appearance. In a duel against '90s heartthrob Ricky Martin, our favorite blonde bombshell pulled out all of her best moves as she channeled Britney Spears for her performance of "...Baby One More Time."
